Traders often draw too many lines, not knowing when/where to pull the trigger.

Here is my secret to drawing SR zones.

Before I draw a zone I ask myself "If price dumps/pumps to this level would I Buy/Sell?

If yes, draw a line.

If no, ignore the level.

Don't overcomplicate.

10/
Remember, mastering the basics beats fragmentary knowledge about advanced indicators every single time.

Now, take what you learned here, find more examples to learn to identify these patterns until they become immediately obvious, and start making money!

9/
So, when you see a trend confirmed by volume, that’s the time to open a position.

When you see a possible reversal, then it’s time to exit or set a stop-loss order.

8/
These simple principles are all you need to start making rational trading decisions.

There are other more advanced indicators based on volume, but you don’t need to worry about these for now.

If you still want to check them out, then start with On Balance Volume (OBV).

7/
Final example: first we have an uptrend confirmed by volume, signaling a continuation, and then a downtrend on decreasing volume, which signals a temporary correction. https://t.co/vkhac1JQRs

6/
Here we have an example of a downtrend with decreasing volume, signaling a reversal.

When the big players see that the trend is likely to reverse, their lack of confidence in the trend is reflected in the volume. The same applies for uptrends. https://t.co/SxTQajXRKK

5/
Here’s an example of a downtrend confirmed by volume.

As the price went down, the volume went up, which signals a continuation of the trend. https://t.co/1Mfst7aO5c

4/
Briefly, increasing volume confirms a trend, while decreasing volume signals a possible reversal.

Uptrend on increasing volume = confirmed, likely to continue.

Uptrend on decreasing volume = possible reversal or fakeout, be careful.

Same works for downtrends as well.

3/
The simplest way to understand why it’s important is that it essentially signals the strength of a trend and warns of a possible reversal.

The biggest movers of volume are the big players. 

You better pay attention to what they’re doing.

2/ 
So, what even is volume?

Sometimes it’s wrongly defined as the NUMBER of trades on a given pair.

What it actually refers to is the total AMOUNT of an asset traded in a given pair and a given time frame.

8/

Key takeaways:

1. BTC dominance can give you a hint in how much exposure you should have to altcoins

2. You shouldn't put all your eggs into one basket

3. Altcoin season is almost upon us

7/

BTC dominance has a few downsides/flaws though. 

Allegedly it doesn’t account for the Bitcoin that has been lost or stolen and it fails to factor BTC’s deep liquidity;

 an altcoin might have a huge, artificially inflated valuation that eats away at BTC dominance.

6/

With Bitcoin dominance sliding ever lower, we can predict a full-fledged altcoin season approaching us very quickly.

5/

This year the BTC dominance was mostly hovering between the 60% and 70% mark. 

Until it really started following the downtrend in the middle of March.

In the past few days, we’ve dipped under 50% for the first time since 2018!

4/

Take a look at the history of BTC dominance.

You will notice that it was quite high in the first years after introduction (mostly above 90%) and at an all-time low of 33% in the start of 2018, when altcoins first started popping off. https://t.co/GWST9Sr7Zm

3/

Why does it even matter? 

Simply put, when Bitcoin dominance goes down, other cryptocurrencies normally go up in price (an opportunity for traders and investors). 

When there's a prolonged period of low BTC dominance, we even declare an »altcoin season«.

2/ 

In a nutshell, Bitcoin dominance is the ratio between the market cap of Bitcoin vs. the market cap of all altcoins. 

For example, if the market cap of all cryptocurrencies (including BTC) is $200 Million and BTC market cap is $100 Million, BTC dominance is at 50%.

What is this #Bitcoin dominance everyone keeps talking about on your thread?! 

A quick educational thread, feel free to retweet or add a comment if you have any questions.

As you might have heard, Bitcoin's dominance is decreasing by the day.

8. That’s it for now, I hope this was helpful. 

Open up some charts and look for these structures to get better at identifying them.

They’re rarely as clean as the pictures above, but with a bit of practice, they become obvious.

7. The same holds for uptrends: two equal lows can be a double bottom that enables the uptrend to continue.

Two equal highs, on the other hand, are a double top if the price closes below the low between them.

6. But keep in mind that a downtrend making the same high as the previous one isn’t a break.

That can be a double top, as you can see below.

On the other hand, two equal lows can be a reversal if they form a double bottom. https://t.co/SKBtIZkZw2

5. So how does a trend reverse?

That happens when the structure is broken, for example, something in a downtrend starts making HHs.

4. The same works for a downtrend: as long as it keeps printing lower highs (LHs) and lower lows (LLs), it’s still in place.

Don’t make the mistake of thinking that a LH is a reversal. https://t.co/fxhTEHLJDu

3. For example, an uptrend is made up of higher highs (HHs) and higher lows (HLs). 

So even if the price is currently heading down, the uptrend is still in place as long as it makes a HL.

And HLs are the best opportunity for buying. https://t.co/8SRsCKGUvK

2. First, we need to keep in mind that prices don’t move in a straight line.

They always zigzag, and that’s why we get highs and lows.

So to identify a trend, don’t look at what the price is doing right now, but rather the sequence of highs and lows.

I’ve been getting a lot of DMs about the basics of trends.

So I’ll answer those questions with a thread: what are higher/lower highs and lows and why do you need to know about them?

1. Simply put, volatility expresses how much the value of an asset moves up and down over a particular time frame.

On its own, volatility is neutral because of this.

3. This gap usually tends to be filled, which means that the price has a tendency to return to Friday’s close.

2. If the price of $BTC moves during the weekend, the CME will open at a higher or lower price compared to Friday’s close.

1. CME stands for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, the world’s largest derivatives exchange, where $BTC has been traded since 2017.

6. To start with, CBDCs will run on closed, government-run networks.

The transactions won’t be public and the source codes sure as hell won’t be open source.

Your identity, however, won’t be private, and the government will be able to monitor everything you do with your funds.

5. Every cryptocurrency, including stablecoins, runs on a public blockchain.

This means that everyone can see the transactions, but no one can see the real identities of the wallets’ owners.

CBDCs will likely be different.

4. Because they are issued by central banks and not private entities, they should be as resistant to malicious acts as traditional fiat.

However, they have some important drawbacks compared to crypto or stablecoins (apart from the economic drawbacks of fiat in general).

3. First of all, CBDCs differ from cryptocurrencies because they have the same value as fiat currencies.

Unlike stablecoins, however, they aren’t pegged to the fiat – they ARE the fiat.

2. This makes them comparable to cryptocurrencies, or at least stablecoins.

So, what are the differences?

1. Firstly, CBDCs aren’t the same as paying with your phone via your bank account, for example, because in the latter case you’re still using traditional fiat stored at the bank.

With a CBDC, you don’t need a bank; you can store your fiat in your own electronic wallet.

7. Whenever the funding rate is high (recently it was up to 0.5% on some pairs), you should be careful as that indicates an overhyped market.

This is why a lot of people were talking about the funding rates recently.

6. A good way to tell how many leveraged positions there are is the funding rate.

The higher the funding rate, the more interest there is for high leverage long positions and vice versa.

5. This liquidates more traders, causing a feedback loop.

The same thing goes for the more famous short squeeze, when shorts are liquidated and the price rises.

4. If there are a lot of long positions with high leverage and the price dips, liquidating those positions, then that will force the price down further.

This is called a long squeeze and happens when one trader is liquidated, his position is sold, forcing the price down further.

3. This tends to happen a lot during periods of volatility such as the past few days.

And when it does, it can have an impact on the price of the asset.

2. For example, if you open a long position worth 0.1 BTC when BTC is at $30,000 with an account balance of $600, and BTC drops by ~20%, you will be liquidated.

You will lose the $600 along with liquidation fees.

1. When you open any kind of a leveraged position, that increases both your potential profits and your risk.

If the position you have goes against your prediction by more than the total balance of your account, you will be liquidated and lose your collateral.

15) So, there’s no magic answer as to what strategy is best in terms of supply.

Nor can there be one best strategy for all coins. Maybe a fixed supply is best for a store of value (BTC) and a slightly inflationary supply for something that has wider use cases (e.g. ETH).

14) Finally, deflationary currencies reduce the supply by burning more tokens than can be minted.

This means that the price of each token increases as time goes on.

13) The drawback is the same as with fiat currencies, although to a much lesser extent, namely that it reduces the price of the currency in proportion to the market cap.

Ethereum is currently inflationary, although this could change in the future.

12) Inflationary cryptocurrencies might seem strange, but they don’t inflate because of the decisions of a central bank.

Rather, the rate of inflation is preset, and it can depend on the number of validator nodes in a predictable way, in order to meet rising demand.

11) Apart from this, cryptocurrencies with a fixed supply don’t have a means of adjusting for changes in supply and demand.

This means that the price will be more volatile, since that is the only possible reaction to an increase in demand.

10) The main problem is that a fixed supply can make it impractical for a cryptocurrency to be used as a means of payment.

For example, if BTC hits $1 million, the transaction fees would make smaller transactions extremely expensive.

9) The oldest model (chosen by BTC) is a fixed supply. BTC’s max supply is fixed at 21 million, and it’s approaching this at a pace that is halved every 4 years.

The good thing about this strategy is its predictability. However, it has some important drawbacks.

8) Crypto isn’t issued by one entity, but can be mined by anyone according to a predetermined set of rules.

These rules determine how much crypto can be added to the supply and at what rate.

There are different strategies for the supply: fixed, inflationary and deflationary.

7) There’s no way around this. Since fiat is centralized and issued by a single entity, it needs to keep adding to the supply to keep the economy afloat.

HOW does crypto differ in this respect?

6) In the US for example, the average inflation rate since 1970 has been 3.87% per year.

So, if you had $1 in 1970, you would need to invest it and make $6.66 by 2020 just in order to break even (that is, to have the same purchasing power as $1 in 1970).

5) In fact, one of the main tasks of central banks is to keep inflation controlled at a couple percent per year.

This is notoriously difficult, but even when it succeeds, you’re still losing 2% of your capital every year.

4) At any point, they can simply decide to print $1 trillion, for example (and, recently, they have done pretty much just that).

If you keep adding to the supply of a currency, what will happen? Its value will drop.

This is called inflation, and it affects all fiat currencies.

3) So, how does this pan out into how valuable they are?

The main difference here is supply. That is, how new coins are minted and introduced into the market.

With fiat, this is controlled by central banks and governments.

2) In fact, the very word “fiat” comes from the Latin expression which means “let it be” (as in “fiat lux” = “let there be light”).

Fiat is essentially centralized and top-down, whereas crypto isn’t controlled by any single entity.

1) Firstly, crypto and fiat differ in the reason they have value.

Crypto has value because the entire crypto community sees it as valuable (see the following for more), whereas fiat has value because a government says so.

8) That’s it for now.

Keep these simple principles in mind and you will be on your way to making more and losing less. Simple as that.

And never ditch the initial R/R of a trade and change the take profit/stop loss without a damn good reason.

Cold and calculated wins the race.

7) If each trade was worth $100, you end up with $120.

Therefore, the higher the likelihood of losing a trade, the lower the R/R ratio should be.

There are other ways to decrease the risk of a trade, such as by hedging through a futures order.

6) Keep in mind that a higher R/R ratio means that you can lose more trades and still make a profit overall.

For example, if you have 4 trades of equal size at an R/R of 1:5, and lose three of them, you’ll end up with a 20% profit on the size of the trades.

5) Rather, a stop loss should be at or slightly below an important support level, and a take profit order at resistance.

When you identify these points, then consider the R/R of the trade.

4) That means you stand to lose 1k or gain 5k. That’s a R/R ratio of 1:5.

But keep in mind that this is just an example, never set a stop loss or take a profit order just in order to have a specific R/R ratio.

3) So what does that mean in practice? In trading, the way you implement R/R ratios is via stop loss and take profit orders.

Say you buy 1 BTC at 20k, set a stop loss at 19k and a take profit order at 25k.

2) Different timeframes and strategies require different R/R ratios.

Most people go for anywhere between 1:2 and 1:10, but a rough average would probably be 1:3.

1) As the name implies, it’s the ratio between what you could lose and what you could gain from a trade or investment.

What is a good number to aim for? Well, that varies. Wildly.

When getting into anything risky, from a trade to a boxing match, you need to know one crucial thing.

What can you gain and what can you lose?

In trading, this is called the RISK/REWARD RATIO.

13)That’s all you need to know about how different stablecoins work and more importantly why they differ.

12)There are other crypto-collateralized stablecoins in various phases of development or adoption, like sUSD and RSV, but DAI is by far the most popular.

In any case, we can expect there to be many more decentralized stablecoins backed by different kinds of assets in the future.

11)DAI is backed by different cryptocurrencies, including BTC, ETH and USDC.

That gives it added security in case one of the collateral assets drops in value.

10)That means that, to mint $100 worth of stablecoins, you need to lock $150 worth of collateral.

The most popular crypto-collateralized stablecoin is DAI, created by Maker.

9)They are typically issued by a smart contract: you lock collateral in the contract and get the stablecoins.

Because the collateral can change in value, they are over-collateralized, normally at 150%.

8)Finally, there are also crypto-collateralized stablecoins.

These coins get around the issue of trusting a single institution by collateralizing with crypto (including other stablecoins).

They can be backed by multiple types of collateral, further increasing security.

7)All of them have gone through extensive audits and are backed 1:1 by reserves.

They’re generally regarded as very safe and differ only in the institutions that issue them (except for  BUSD, which, like PAX, is issued by Paxos).

6)Next up, there are a few tokens that are very similar and we’ll cover them as a group.

These are $USDC, $TUSD, $GUSD, $PAX and $BUSD.

5)There was also some controversy with Tether refusing third-party audits.

However, it remains the most popular option due to its widespread use.

4)To start with, Tether( $USDT ) is by far the most popular stablecoin, with a market cap of $20 billion.

It is also somewhat controversial, since the issuer admitted that USDT is partly backed by their loans to third parties and not only by reserves.

3)This is necessary because the issuer has to prove that, at any point, you can exchange your stablecoins for USD.

That redeemability is what keeps the value of a stablecoin equal to 1 USD.

2)Fiat-collateralized stablecoins work like this:

The issuer receives a certain amount of USD and then issues the corresponding number of stablecoin tokens.

The USD must be held in reserve by the issuer as long as the stablecoin tokens are in circulation.

1)Stablecoins are blockchain-based tokens that are pegged to a fiat currency.

$USD stablecoins are by far the most popular.

Let's go through fiat-collateralized coins first, and then the most popular crypto-collateralized ones.

In days of high volatility, stablecoins seem like saviors from heaven🔒

But with the variety of different ones available, even experienced traders often don’t know the differences and how they work.

This requires more skill in technical analysis, but fundamentals are much less important for day trading. https://t.co/b0UvFUddIQ

5)Next up is DAY TRADING.

This is an even more hands-on approach, and it’s called day trading because all positions are opened and closed on the same day.

4)If you want to take a more active approach, then maybe SWING TRADING is for you.

Swing traders typically keep positions open from days to weeks, so they need a healthy mix of technicals and fundamentals. https://t.co/MeKTNZRNKn

3)Investing is the best way to get into crypto, because it doesn’t require a lot of technical analysis.

However, if you want to invest in altcoins, you need to know the fundamentals (read my thread on alts research).

If it’s just #BTC, you’re good to go. Stack sats and chill.

2)Starting from the longest timeframe, investors or position traders hold assets for weeks, months or years.

In crypto, that’s called HODLING.

Profitable and easy, but requires patience. https://t.co/mcgLriFsfS

1)Simply put, the difference between the types of traders is based on the timeframes that they trade.

But that has implications for their methods too: a scalp trader and an investor need to use completely different tools if they want to succeed.

You may have heard of INVESTORS, SWING TRADERS, DAY TRADERS, and SCALPERS.

But where exactly is the difference between them?

More importantly, what should YOU do to find what works for you?

7/ Finally, don’t ever think that there’s no room for improvement.

There’s always stuff to learn, books to read, and projects to discover.

The only way to improve is to have that kind of growth mindset.

Look out for the mistakes above and learn/study them. 

Simple as that.

6/ Nothing is 100% in trading. The market is a probability distribution, not a mathematical equation.

The point is to learn those probabilities and use them in your favor.

5/ So, take the time to study one indicator at a time, and when you’re comfortable with it, move on to the next one.

And don’t think that an approach is useless just because you were wrong about a prediction.

4/ Now, don’t go the other way and try to learn as many approaches as possible, but without looking into them in any depth.

That will lead you to misuse indicators. 

And because you’re trying to do everything at once, it will be hard to know what exactly you’re doing wrong.

3/ Next up is marrying an approach or an indicator.

When I was starting out, I thought that MA crosses were all I need to know.

Needless to say, my first months weren’t great.

Explore. Learn. Improve.

2/ Better yet, only trade very small sums for the first few months at least or even do paper trading.

That way, you’ll learn what works without losing too much money.

When you see that your PNL% is consistently decent, then you can start trading larger sums.

1/ The first one is risking too much of your portfolio on one trade.

If you can avoid this, other mistakes will cost you much less, even if you make them.

As a rule of thumb, never risk more than 10% of your portfolio on one trade.

6) Apart from this, use common sense when storing data such as passwords.

5) Then, make sure you enable 2-factor authentication, preferably on a dedicated device.

Never put all of your eggs in one basket when it comes to security, regardless of how safe one device is.

4) Make sure that any withdrawal always requires confirmation from a safe email.

That way, even if someone steals your exchange account, they can’t do anything with it.

Well, maybe they could make your portfolio 100% Dogecoin, so still be careful about those accounts.

3) That device needs to be as safe as possible.

2) First, have a dedicated computer ONLY for logging into the email accounts that you use for crypto.

The latter could give its users a tokenized version of staked ETH, effectively a replacement that they can trade or use as collateral.

WEAK Bullish Divergence.

The price forms a lower low, and the oscillator forms a double bottom. https://t.co/pHg8DWa7Kh

MEDIUM Bullish Divergence.

This happens when the price forms a double bottom, and the momentum oscillator makes a higher low. https://t.co/dXWS7nkbrp

STRONG Bullish Divergence.

This happens when the price of an asset makes a lower low, but the momentum oscillator makes a higher low. 
This means that the price is probably going to form a bottom. https://t.co/NXSpxcnhkq

There are 3 TYPES of BULLISH divergences, which are determined by its strength. Strong, medium, and weak.

We will show an example of every type!

IMPORTANT
- Always observe the lows of the price and the oscillator.
- When determining the divergence, look for clear new levels (Higher High, Higher Low, or Lower High nad Lower Lows). 
- Never use divergences in a sideways trend.

A bullish divergence is formed when the price moves in a downtrend, and it is about to reverse.

When determining the bullish divergence, we always have to look at the lows of the price and the oscillator. 
This way, we determine a bottom. https://t.co/BsL1pnGbU8

A BULLISH DIVERGENCE is used for predicting the tops and bottoms.

It’s basically the opposite of bearish signals.

Traders use bullish divergences to time their ENTRY points of a trade.

A Divergence is a term describing the occurrence when the price and the momentum oscillator move in DIFFERENT directions. 

Divergences are used to identify the potential REVERSAL of a trend. They work better when using a longer time frame (4-hour or daily time frame).
USUALLY when the price of a certain asset moves in a certain direction the momentum oscillator moves in the SAME direction too. https://t.co/C8b2gNP436

To understand the divergence, we have to get to know another term called an OSCILLATOR. 

An oscillator is a momentum indicator used in technical analysis that moves between an upper and lower band. 

For example, the Relative Strength Index or RSI.

<>BULLISH DIVERGENCE<>
